awd_titl_txt: Determining How Plasma Spontaneously Develops a Localized Hot Spot That Radiates X-rays and Produces Related Dramatic Phenomena
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will experimentally explore the eruptive behavior of a plasma, a gas of electrically charged ions and electrons, under conditions similar to those on the sun and in other astrophysical objects.  This will be done by creating plasma jets in a vacuum chamber and observing how they can erupt by exhibiting sudden and dramatic dynamic behaviors mimicking the eruptive behaviors associated with solar flares, astrophysical gamma ray bursts, and X-rays from lightening. The research program will build and use new diagnostic instruments that will measure the eruptive behavior and test the hypothesis that eruption results when an instability tries to interrupt the electric current in a plasma jet. The project will engage a local high school with a vast majority of students from under-represented minority groups to have students build a device that measures the concentration of atmospheric charged particles, thereby motivating interest in science and encouraging them to pursue careers in plasma physics or other science and engineering fields. 

The research program will determine how a seemingly benign, cold, collisional plasma can suddenly erupt and generate a burst of energetic particles, extreme ultra-violet radiation, hard X-rays, and high-frequency waves. In doing so, it will contribute to the goals of NSF's "Windows on the Universe: The Era of Multi-Messenger Astrophysics" Big Idea.  The knowledge and understanding to be gained will apply to many astrophysical and laboratory plasmas, such as solar flares, astrophysical gamma ray bursts, X-ray bursts from terrestrial lightning, and dense plasma foci devices. The program will employ a well-diagnosed, reproducible laboratory device in which an initially cold plasma spontaneously erupts and generates these bursts. The details of the eruptive process have been partly established via high-speed imaging of visible light and extreme ultraviolet radiation, via X-ray measurements, and via whistler wave measurements. New diagnostics will be constructed to measure previously unquantified aspects of the eruptive process such as rapid density depletion, rapid particle heating, and rapid development of strong localized electric and magnetic fields. These diagnostics will image highly localized reductions of density and increases of temperature associated with the eruption. These new measurements will be modeled using advanced analytic and numerical methods.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Magnetically dominated plasmas lasting a few tens of microseconds with large electric currents and human-scale dimensions were reproducibly created in a laboratory vacuum chamber about the size of small car. Depending on the electrode configuration, these plasmas are small-scale replicas of either solar corona loops or astrophysical jets. The lab plasmas can replicate these solar and astrophysical plasmas because the relevant plasma physics has no intrinsic scale so all these plasmas are governed by the same equations and thus have similar dynamical behavior.  The lab plasmas, the solar plasmas, and the astrophysical plasmas are all modeled by magnetohydrodynamics (MHD), a macroscopic point of view that models plasma as being a superconducting gas so that the magnetic field is frozen into the plasma and so moves together with the plasma.  In contrast to solar and astrophysical plasmas, the lab plasma is reproducible and its parameters can be adjusted.   This reproducibility and controllability enables lab plasma behavior to be investigated in detail so important insights and critical understanding are obtained that are pertinent to solar and astrophysical plasmas.

The lab plasmas exhibit complex, well-defined dynamical sequences. The jet plasma has the sequence of:

(i) jet formation,

(ii) development of a kink instability when the jet reaches a critical length at which the jet becomes an exponentially growing corkscrew,  

(iii) development of a faster and smaller scale Rayleigh-Taylor instability (heavy fluid on top of light fluid), as a consequence of the acceleration associated with the kink corkscrew growth providing an enormous effective gravity,

(iv) choking of the electric current flow in the jet by the Rayleigh-Taylor ripples so that electron flow speeds up, like putting a finger on a garden hose to get a fast spray,

(v) some electrons speeding up to such a high velocity that when they collide with an atom, they cause the atom to emit X-rays over 3000 times more energetic than the original plasma.

A similar sequence is observed with solar corona loop replicas but, instead of a single jet going unstable, two braided magnetic structures have separate instability sequences so that a double burst of X-rays is observed.

These phenomena were measured using a high-speed movie camera (several million frames per second), X-ray cameras, as well as measurements of electric current (50-100 kiloamps) and potential (several kilovolts).

An important result was identifying and understanding the coupling between MHD and finer scale models that transcend MHD by taking into account microscopic behavior overlooked by MHD. Because MHD is based on certain simplifying assumptions, it fails when these assumptions are violated. This failure occurs at very small spatial scales and so at these scales the microscopic non-MHD models take over and predict behavior beyond the scope of MHD. The jet, kink, and Rayleigh Taylor instabilities can be described by MHD but not the process where electrons are accelerated to high velocities such that X-rays are produced. This project has shown that MHD contains the seeds of its own destruction because the observed MHD instability sequence causes the plasma to enter a regime where the approximations underlying MHD fail.

In addition to and in support of the experimental work, associated theoretical models have been developed. The experimental results were interpreted using theoretical models scaled to solar and astrophysical dimensions so as to give predictions for solar and astrophysical phenomena. One model shows that the loss of electron energy that occurs when an electron excites an ion so that the ion emits a photon. This process enables a situation where most electrons lose energy but a few lucky electrons never come close enough to an ion to cause photon emission. These lucky electrons never lose energy, are continuously accelerated in a transient electric field produced by an instability, and so constitute an energetic tail that ultimately can produce the observed X-rays. A second model showed how a non-MHD instability previously thought to require no collisions can develop in a situation where the electron collision frequency is so high as to dwarf most other characteristic frequencies. A third model shows how collisions between neutral atoms and electrons or ions in an accretion disk orbiting a new-born star will cause a radial separation of the electrons from the ions and a loss of angular momentum of the neutrals.
